Human-Feedback Efficient
Reinforcement Learning for Online Diffusion Model Finetuning

Ayano HiranakaÂ Â 1,3Â Â Â Shang-Fu Chen11footnotemark: 1Â Â 1,2Â Â Â Chieh-Hsin Lai11footnotemark: 1Â Â 1
Dongjun Kim4Â Â Â Naoki Murata1Â Â Â Takashi Shibuya1Â Â Â Wei-Hsiang Liao1
Shao-Hua SunÂ Â 2Â Â Â Yuki Mitsufuji22footnotemark: 2Â Â 1
1Sony AI, 2 Graduate Institute of Communication Engineering, National Taiwan University,
3University of Southern California, 4Stanford University Equal contributions. This work was done while Ayano Hiranaka and Shang-Fu Chen interned at Sony AI. Correspondence to: Ayano Hiranaka <<<ahiranak@usc.edu>>> and Shang-Fu Chen <<<f07942144@ntu.edu.tw>>>Equal advisory.
Abstract

Controllable generation through Stable Diffusion (SD) fine-tuning aims to improve fidelity, safety, and alignment with human guidance. Existing reinforcement learning from human feedback methods usually rely on predefined heuristic reward functions or pretrained reward models built on large-scale datasets, limiting their applicability to scenarios where collecting such data is costly or difficult. To effectively and efficiently utilize human feedback, we develop a framework, HERO, which leverages online human feedback collected on the fly during model learning. Specifically, HERO features two key mechanisms: (1) Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning, an online training method that captures human feedback and provides informative learning signals for fine-tuning, and (2) Feedback-Guided Image Generation, which involve generating images from SDâ€™s refined initialization samples, enabling faster convergence towards the evaluatorâ€™s intent. We demonstrate that HERO is 4Ã—4\times4 Ã— more efficient in online feedback for body part anomaly correction compared to the best existing method. Additionally, experiments show that HERO can effectively handle tasks like reasoning, counting, personalization, and reducing NSFW content with only 0.5K online feedback.

1 Introduction

Controllable text-to-image (T2I) generation focuses on aligning model outputs with user intent, such as producing realistic images, e.g.,Â undistorted human bodies, or accurately reflecting the count, semantics, and attributes specified by users. To tackle this problem, a common paradigm involves fine-tuning latent diffusion models (DM) like Stable DiffusionÂ (SD; Rombach etÂ al., 2022) using supervised fine-tuningÂ (SFT; Lee etÂ al., 2023), which mostly learn from pre-collected, offline datasets. To further enhance the alignment, online reinforcement learning (RL) fine-tuning methods Â (Fan etÂ al., 2024; Black etÂ al., 2024) utilize online feedback that specifically evaluates the samples generated by the model during training. With such dynamic guidance provided on the fly, these methods demonstrate superior performance on various T2I tasks, such as aesthetic quality improvement. Yet, these approaches rely on either predefined heuristic reward functions or pretrained reward models learned from large-scale datasets, which could be challenging to obtain, especially for tasks involving personalized content generation (e.g.,Â capturing cultural nuances) or concepts like specific colors or compositions.

To address the above issue, Yang etÂ al. (2024b) introduces D3PO, an alternative method that directly leverages online human feedback for fine-tuning diffusion models. Instead of learning from heuristic reward functions or pretrained reward models, D3PO leverages the samples generated by the model as well as human annotations collected during training. With online human feedback, D3PO addresses various tasks, such as distorted human body correction and NSFW content prevention, without requiring a pretrained reward model for each individual task. However, it still necessitates approximately 5K instances of online human feedback during trainingÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024b; Uehara etÂ al., 2024), placing a significant burden on the human evaluator and restricting the use of customized fine-tuning to match individual preferences.

To further improve the feedback efficiency of T2I alignment using online human feedback, this work proposes a Human-feedback Efficient Reinforcement learning for Online diffusion model fine-tuning framework, dubbed HERO, to efficiently and effectively utilize online human feedback to fine-tune a SD model, as illustrated inÂ FigureÂ 1. Specifically, we propose two novel components: (1) Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning, an online-trained embedding map that creates a representation space that implicitly captures human preferences and provides continuous reward signals for RL fine-tuning, and (2) Feedback-Guided Image Generation, which involve generating images from SDâ€™s refined initialization samples aligned with human intent, for faster convergence to the evaluatorâ€™s preferences.

Feedback-aligned representation learning (FigureÂ 1â€™s \raisebox{-.9pt} {\footnotesize1}âƒ) aims to create a representation space that implicitly reflects human preferences, offering continuous reward signals for RL fine-tining. At each epoch, SD generates a batch of images, and a human evaluator classifies the images as â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€, selecting one â€œbestâ€ image from the â€œgoodâ€ set. The latents of the human-annotated images are then employed to train an embedding map through contrastive learningÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2020), aiming to develop a feedback-aligned representation space. By calculating the cosine similarity to the â€œbestâ€ representation vector in the learned representation space, we obtain a continuous evaluation for each latent. Subsequently, we utilize the computed similarity as continuous reward signals to fine-tune SD via LoRAÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2022).

After fine-tuning the SD for the first iteration, our feedback-guided image generation (FigureÂ 1â€™s \raisebox{-.9pt} {\footnotesize2}âƒ) samples a new batch of images from a Gaussian mixture centered on the stored â€œgoodâ€ and â€œbestâ€ initial noises from the previous iteration. This process facilitates the generation of images that align with human intentions better than random initial noises, thereby enhancing the efficiency of fine-tuning. HERO effectively achieves controllable T2I generation with minimal online human feedback through iterative feedback-guided image generation, feedback-aligned representation learning, and SD model finetuning.

We conduct extensive experiments on various T2I tasks to compare HERO with existing methods. The experimental results show that HERO can effectively fine-tune SD to reliably follow given text prompts with 4Ã—4\times4 Ã— fewer amount of human feedback compared to D3POÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024b). On the other hand, the results show that these tasks are difficult to solve through prompt enhancementÂ (Winata etÂ al., 2024) or fine-tuning approaches, e.g.,Â DreamBoothÂ (Ruiz etÂ al., 2023), that rely on a few reference imagesÂ (Gal etÂ al., 2023). FigureÂ 2 presents a preview of the results. Extensive ablation studies verify the effectiveness of our proposed feedback-aligned representation learning and the technique of generating images from refined noises. Additionally, we show that the model fine-tuned by HERO demonstrates transferability to previously unseen inference prompts, showcasing that the desired concepts were acquired by the model.

2 Related Works

Recent research has explored controllable generation with SD for tasks like T2I alignmentÂ (Black etÂ al., 2024; Prabhudesai etÂ al., 2023), conceptual generationÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024a; Zhong etÂ al., 2023), correcting generation flawsÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2023), personalizationÂ (Gal etÂ al., 2023; Ruiz etÂ al., 2023) and removing NSFW contentÂ (Gandikota etÂ al., 2023; Kumari etÂ al., 2023; Lu etÂ al., 2024).

Supervised fine-tuning. DreamBoothÂ (DB; Ruiz etÂ al., 2023) and Textual InversionÂ (Gal etÂ al., 2023) take images as input and fine-tunes SD via supervised learning to learn the specific subject present in the input images. However, such methods require reference images, limiting their applicability to general T2I tasks, such as conceptual generation, e.g.,Â emotional image content generationÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024a), or accurately reflecting user-specified counts, semantics, and attributesÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2024). On the other hand, Prabhudesai etÂ al. (2023); Gandikota etÂ al. (2023); Xu etÂ al. (2024); Clark etÂ al. (2024) use pretrained reward models to calculate differentiable gradients for SD fine-tuning. However, such pretrained models are not always accessible for tasks of interest, and moreover, these methods cannot directly utilize human feedback, which is non-differentiable.

RL fine-tuning. Various methods have explored incorporating non-differentiable signals, such as human feedback, as rewards to fine-tune SD using RL. For example, DDPOÂ (Black etÂ al., 2024) uses predefined reward functions for tasks like compressibility, DPOKÂ (Fan etÂ al., 2024) leverages feedback from an AI model trained on a large-scale human dataset, and SEIKOÂ (Uehara etÂ al., 2024) obtain rewards from custom reward functions trained from extensive feedback datasets. Yet, these methods require a predefined reward function or reward model, which can be difficult to obtain for tasks that involve generating personalized content (e.g.,Â reflecting cultural nuances) or abstract concepts, such as specific colors or compositionsÂ (Amadeus etÂ al., 2024; Kannen etÂ al., 2024).

Direct preference optimization (DPO). Diffusion-DPOÂ (Wallace etÂ al., 2023) applies DPOÂ (Rafailov etÂ al., 2023) to directly utilize preference data to fine-tune SD, eliminating the need for predefined rewards. Despite encouraging their results, such a method requires a large-scale pre-collected human preference dataset e.g.,Â Diffusion-DPO uses the Pick-a-Pic dataset with 851K preference pairs, making it costly to collect and limiting its applicability to various tasks, including personalization. Instead of leveraging offline datasets, D3POÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024b) uses online human feedback collected on-the-fly during model training for DPO-style finetuning of SD. It demonstrates success in tasks such as body part deformation correction and content safety improvement while avoiding the demand for large-scale offline datasets. However, the amount of human feedback required for D3PO is still high, requiring 5-10k feedback instances per task, which motivates us to develop a more human-feedback-efficient framework.

4 Problem Setup and the Proposed Method

Given a user-specified text prompt, our goal is to fine-tune SD to generate images that align with the prompt by learning from human feedback guidance. In this paper, we focus on challenging T2I tasks that require spatial reasoning, counting, feasibility understanding, etc., as detailed inÂ TableÂ 1. To efficiently and effectively utilize online human feedback, we propose a human-feedback efficient reinforcement learning for online diffusion model fine-tuning framework, dubbed HERO, as illustrated inÂ FigureÂ 1. Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning (FigureÂ 1 \raisebox{-.9pt} {\footnotesize1}âƒ) makes efficient use of limited human feedback by converting discrete feedback to informative, continuous reward signals. In addition, Feedback-Guided Image Generation (FigureÂ 1 \raisebox{-.9pt} {\footnotesize2}âƒ) leverages human-preferred noise latents from previous iterations and encourages SD outputs to align more quickly with human intention, further improving sample efficiency.

4.1 Online Human Feedback

4.2 Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning

HERO fine-tunes SD with minimal online human feedback by learning representations via a contrastive objective that captures discrepancies between the best SDâ€™s clean latent ğ³Tbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘‡best{\mathbf{z}}_{T}^{\text{best}}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, positive ğ’µ0+subscriptsuperscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}^{+}_{0}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and negative ğ’µ0âˆ’subscriptsuperscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}^{-}_{0}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT SDâ€™s clean latents (SectionÂ 4.2.1). By calculating similarity to the best imageâ€™s representation, we use these similarity scores as continuous rewards for RL fine-tuning (SectionÂ 4.2.2). This approach bypasses reward model training by directly converting human feedback into learning signals, avoiding the need for over 100k training samples typically required to train a reward model for unseen dataÂ (Wallace etÂ al., 2023; Rafailov etÂ al., 2023).

5 Experimental Results

We demonstrate HEROâ€™s performance on a variety of tasks, including hand deformation correction, content safety improvement, reasoning, and personalization. Many of them cannot be easily solved by the pretrained model, prompt enhancement, or prior methods. A full list of tasks and their success conditions are shown inÂ TableÂ 1. We adopt SD v1.5Â (Rombach etÂ al., 2022) as the base T2I model, using DDIMÂ (Ho etÂ al., 2020; Song etÂ al., 2020a) with 50 diffusion steps (20 for hand deformation correction for fair comparison to the baselines) as the sampler.

We compare HERO to the following baselines:

  • â€¢

    SD-pretrained prompts the pretrained SD model with the original task prompt shown inÂ TableÂ 1.

  • â€¢

    SD-enhanced prompts the pretrained SD model with an enhanced version of the prompt generated by GPT-4Â (Brown, 2020; Achiam etÂ al., 2023).

  • â€¢

    DreamBoothÂ (DB; Ruiz etÂ al., 2023) finetunes diffusion models via supervised learning, taking images as input. We use the four best images chosen by the human evaluators as model inputs.

  • â€¢

    D3POÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2024b) utilize online human feedback for DPOÂ (Rafailov etÂ al., 2023)-based diffusion model finetuning. Due to the high feedback cost for training, this baseline is considered only for the hand anomaly correction task directly adopted from their work. Success rates are reported as presented in the original paper.

5.1 Hand Deformation Correction

Following the problem setup of D3PO (Yang etÂ al., 2024b), we use the prompt â€œ1 handâ€ for image generation and use human discretion to evaluate the normalcy of the generated hand images. Parameters such as sampling steps are set to be consistent with D3PO. In each epoch of HERO, feedback on 128 images is collected, and the human evaluator provides a total of 1152 feedback over 9 epochs. Performance of HERO in comparison to the baselines is shown inÂ FigureÂ 3. As shown inÂ FigureÂ 3, the pretrained SD model struggles on this task, with a normalcy rate of 11.9% (SD-pretrained) and 7.5% (SD-enhanced), and DB achieves 28%. D3PO reaches 33.3% normalcy rate at 5K feedback, while HERO achieves a comparable success rate of 34.2% with only 1152 feedback (over 4Ã—\timesÃ— more feedback efficient). The sampled images are shown inÂ FigureÂ 8 in the appendix.

5.2 Demonstration on the Variety of Tasks

We further demonstrate the effectivity of HERO on a variety of tasks involving reasoning, correction, feasibility and functionality quality enhancement, and personalization. Tasks are listed inÂ TableÂ 1, and descriptions of task success conditions and task categories are found inÂ AppendixÂ C. For each task, human evaluators are presented with 64 images per epoch and provide a total of 512 feedback over 8 epochs. We report the average and standard deviation of the success rates across three seeds, where success is evaluated on 64 images generated in the final epoch. For methods that require human feedback (DB and HERO), three different human evaluators were each assigned a different seed to provide feedback on. Each evaluator was also responsible for evaluating the success rates of all methods for their assigned seed. Results are shown inÂ TableÂ 2. For all tasks, HERO achieves a success rate at or above 75%, outperforming all baselines. This trend is consistent for all three human evaluators, suggesting HEROâ€™s robustness to individual differences among human evaluators. Sample images generated by SD-pretrained, DB, and HERO are shown inÂ FigureÂ 4 and more results can be found inÂ FiguresÂ 9, 10, 11 andÂ 12 in the appendix. While the baselines often struggle in attribute reasoning (e.g.,Â color, count), spatial reasoning (e.g.,Â inside), and feasibility (e.g.,Â reflection consistent with the subject), HERO models consistently capture these aspects correctly.

5.3 Ablations

This section presents ablation studies illustrating the roles of each component of HERO. In regards to Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning, we investigate the effects of (1) computation of rewards using learnable feedback-aligned representations and (2) â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ design for reward computation. For Feedback-Guided Image Generation, the effect of best image ratio is explored.

5.3.1 Effect of Feedback-Aligned Representation Learning and Reward Design

The effects of using learned feedback-aligned representations and our reward design are investigated through three ablation experiments. Firstly, we demonstrate the benefit of converting discrete human feedback into continuous reward signal by investigating HERO-binary, a variant of HERO using binary rewards for training. Secondly, we explore the effect of learned representations by replacing the learned representations in HERO with SD image latents ğ’µ0+superscriptsubscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}_{0}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (HERO-noEmbed). Finally, we explain our choice for the â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ reward design by discussing an alternative reward design using similarity to the average of all ğ’µ0+superscriptsubscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}_{0}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and z0bestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§0bestz_{0}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (HERO-positives). For each setting, we test on the narcissus task with 512 feedback for training and 200 images generated by the finetuned model for success rate evaluation. HERO outperforms all other settings, and results are summarized inÂ TableÂ 3.

Directly using human labels as binary rewards. An intuitive way to extract a reward signal from binary human feedback is to directly convert the feedback into a binary reward. To investigate the effect of similarity-based conversion of human feedback to continuous rewards, we test HERO-binary, a variant where the reward in HERO is replaced with a binary reward. Images labeled as â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbestâ€ receive a reward of 1.0, and all other images receive a reward of 0.0. HERO-binary only reaches 78% success rate while HERO reaches 91%. This may be because the continuous rewards contain additional information beneficial for DDPO training: While the binary reward only labels images as â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€, the continuous reward additionally captures a gradation of human ratings within the â€œgoodâ€ and â€œbadâ€ categories, supplying additional information such as which â€œgoodâ€ images are nearly â€œbestâ€, and which are barely â€œgoodâ€.

Computing rewards from pretrained image representations. Experiments with binary rewards showed the benefit of using continuous rewards in the learned representation space. To further understand HEROâ€™s use of feedback-aligned learned representations, we replace the learned representations EÎ¸â¢(ğ’µ0)subscriptğ¸ğœƒsubscriptğ’µ0E_{\theta}(\mathcal{Z}_{0})italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with SDâ€™s clean latents ğ’µ0subscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}_{0}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, obtained by denoising SDâ€™s initial noises ğ’µTsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and call this setup HERO-noEmbed. Without embedding map training, ğ’µ0+superscriptsubscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}_{0}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT no longer cluster around z0bestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§0bestz_{0}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, making a â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ reward design impractical. Thus, we only consider the â€œsimilarity-to-positivesâ€ reward design for this ablation. While HERO-positives reach 82% success, HERO-noEmbed reaches 76%, suggesting the benefit of learned representations. Training the embedding map additionally offers the â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ reward design option that gives superior performance.

Computing reward as similarity to average of all â€œgoodâ€ representations. The reward in HERO is computed as the similarity to z0bestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§0bestz_{0}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. However, another natural choice is to compute similarity to the average of all ğ’µ0+superscriptsubscriptğ’µ0\mathcal{Z}_{0}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Comparing this â€œsimilarity-to-positivesâ€ design to the â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ design employed in HERO, we find that the â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ design achieves 91% success, while the â€œsimilarity-to-positivesâ€ design reaches 82%. We adopt the â€œsimilarity-to-bestâ€ design, which empirically gives superior performance.

5.3.2 Effect of Best Image Ratio in Feedback-Guided Image Generation

To investigate the effect of the best image ratio, we compare the performance of the black-cat task for Î²=0.0,0.5,1.0ğ›½0.00.51.0\beta=0.0,0.5,1.0italic_Î² = 0.0 , 0.5 , 1.0. Further, we compare to the case where the images are sampled from random SD noise latents to demonstrate the benefit of using ğ’µT+superscriptsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as initial noises for image generation. Results are shown inÂ FigureÂ 5. Sampling all images from the zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Î²=1.0ğ›½1.0\beta=1.0italic_Î² = 1.0) reaches an average of 70.8%percent70.870.8\%70.8 % success at the end of the training. However, as the high standard deviation in the initial stage of training suggests, over-exploiting a single â€œbestâ€ noise latent can cause instability in training, potentially causing the model to settle on a suboptimal output. Sampling uniformly from ğ’µT+superscriptsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Î²=0.0ğ›½0.0\beta=0.0italic_Î² = 0.0) results in a similar success rate as Î²=1.0ğ›½1.0\beta=1.0italic_Î² = 1.0, but is less likely to converge to a suboptimal point. We empirically find that, for our tasks, Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5italic_Î² = 0.5 results in the highest success rate while avoiding the risks of fully relying on the single â€œbestâ€ noise latent, thus using Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5italic_Î² = 0.5 for our experiments. When images are sampled from random SD noise latents, the task success rate does not grow significantly slower in the given amount of feedback, demonstrating the benefit of using ğ’µT+superscriptsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for efficient fine-tuning.

5.4 Transferability

While HERO is trained to optimize for a single input prompt, we observe that some personal preferences and general concepts learned from one prompt can generalize to other related prompts in some cases.

Transfer of personal preference. In the mountain task, we observe the transfer of learned individual preferences. Two human evaluators trained two separate models for the mountain task, where one evaluator preferred green scenery while the other preferred snowy scenery. Each evaluatorâ€™s trained model as well as the corresponding ğ’µT+superscriptsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are used to generate images for a related task â€œhiker watching beautiful mountains from the top of a hillâ€. As shown inÂ FigureÂ 6, the preference for green or snowy scenery transfers to this new task.

Transfer of content safety. To further investigate whether a general concept, such as content safety, learned through one task can transfer to another, we prompt the SD model using the prompt â€œsexyâ€ and train it to reduce NSFW content in the generated images. The fine-tuned model (as well as the saved ğ’µT+superscriptsubscriptğ’µğ‘‡\mathcal{Z}_{T}^{+}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and zTbestsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘‡bestz_{T}^{\text{best}}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT best end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) are used to generate images from a set of 14 potentially-unsafe prompts used in D3POâ€™s content safety task. Utilizing the finetuned model and the saved SD noise latents significantly improves the content safety rate from 57.5% of the pretrained SD model to 87.0%, demonstrating HERO-finetuned modelâ€™s potential to transfer a general concept learned from one prompt to a set of related, unseen prompts. Visual results are shown inÂ FigureÂ 7, and the full list of prompts with more results are shown inÂ FigureÂ 13 in the appendix.

6 Conclusion

This work introduces HERO, an RLHF framework for fine-tuning SD using online human feedback. By learning a feedback-aligned representation, we capture implicit human preferences, converting simple human feedback into a continuous reward signal that enhances DDPO fine-tuning. Using human-preferred image noise latents as initial noise further accelerates alignment with preferences. Combining these components, HERO achieves high efficiency in fine-tuning SD, requiring 4Ã—4\times4 Ã— less feedback than the baseline. Additionally, it shows potential for transferring personal preferences and concepts to related tasks.

Appendix B Additional Experiments

B.1 RL Fine-tuning with Existing Reward Models

To investigate the benefits of leveraging online human feedback, we compare our HERO to DDPOÂ (Black etÂ al., 2024) with PickScore-v1Â (Kirstain etÂ al., 2023) as the reward model on reasoning and personalization tasks in this paper. PickScore-v1Â (Kirstain etÂ al., 2023) is pretrained on 584K preference pairs and aims to evaluate the general human preference for t2I generation. For the DDPO baseline, we use the same training setting as our HERO and increase the training epochs from 8888 to 50505050. The success rate is calculated using 200 evaluation images.

As shown in TableÂ 4, using DDPO with a large-scale pretrained model as the reward model can not address these tasks easily. Moreover, in the mountain task, the success rate is even worse than the pretrained SD model. A possible reason is that the target of this task (viewed from a train window) contradicts the general human preference, where a landscape with no window is usually preferred. The above results verify that existing large-scale datasets for general t2I alignment may not be suitable for specific reasoning and personalization tasks. Although one could collect large-scale datasets for every task of interest, our online fine-tuning method provides an efficient solution without such extensive labor.

B.3 DreamBooth Prompting Experiments

To investigate the effect of training prompt, class prompt, and generation prompt selection on the performance of our tasks, we test various prompt combinations with the narcissus task. For the training prompt, we consider specific (â€œ[V] narcissusâ€) and general (â€œ[V] flowerâ€) prompts, where â€œ[V]â€ is a unique token. We test three class prompts: the most general â€œflowerâ€, one that specifies the type of subject (â€œnarcissus flowerâ€), and one that uses a general term describing the subject but specifies the context (â€œflower by a quiet spring and its reflection in the waterâ€). Similarly, we test three generation prompts with different levels of specificity. Results are shown inÂ TableÂ 6. While most settings achieve over 90%percent9090\%90 % success rate, we select setting 7 with high visual quality and closest alignment with the prompt selection used in the original paperâ€™s experiments.

Appendix C Details of Tasks and Task Categories

Here, we provide the detailed success conditions the human evaluators were provided with and explanations of each task category.

Detailed Task Success Conditions

  • â€¢

    hand: A hand has exactly five fingers with exactly one thumb, and the pose is physically feasible.

  • â€¢

    blue-rose: The generated subject is a rose and has the correct color (blue), count (one), and context (inside a vase).

  • â€¢

    black-cat: A single cat with the correct color (black) and action (sitting inside a box) is generated. The catâ€™s pose is feasible, with no parts of the body penetrating the box. The cardboard is shaped like a functional box.

  • â€¢

    narcissus: The image correctly captures the narcissus flower, rather than the mythological figure, as the subject. Reflection in the water contains, and only contains, subjects present in the scene, and the appearance of reflections is consistent with the subject(s).

  • â€¢

    mountain: View of the mountains is from a train window. The body of the train the mountain is seen from is not in the view. If other trains or rails are in view, they are not oriented in a way that may cause collision. Any rails in the view are functional (do not make 90-degree turns, for instance).

Description of Task Categories

  • â€¢

    Correction: Removing distortions or defects in the generated image. For example, generating non-distorted human limbs.

  • â€¢

    Reasoning: Capturing object attributes (e.g., color or texture), spatial relationships (e.g., on top of, next to), and non-spatial relationships (e.g., looking at, wearing).

  • â€¢

    Counting: Generating the correct number of specified objects.

  • â€¢

    Feasibility: Whether the characteristics of generated images are attainable in the real world. For example, the pose of articulated objects is physically possible, or reflections are consistent with the subject.

  • â€¢

    Functionality: For objects with certain functionalities (such as boxes or rails), the object is shaped in a way that makes the object usable for this function.

  • â€¢

    Homonym Distinction: Understanding the desired subject among input prompts containing homonyms.

  • â€¢

    Personalization: Aligning to personal preferences, such as preference for certain colors, styles, or compositions.

Appendix D HERO Implementation

D.1 HERO Detailed Algorithm

In this section, we summarize the algorithm of HERO as presented in AlgorithmÂ 1. In the first iteration, the human evaluator selects â€goodâ€ and â€bestâ€ images from the batch generated by the pretrained SD model. This method assumes the model can generate prompt-matching images with non-zero probability and focuses on increasing the ratio of successful images rather than producing previously unattainable ones.

D.2 HERO Training Parameters

HERO consists of four main steps: Online human feedback, representation learning for reward value computation, finetuning of SD, and image sampling from human-chosen SD latents. Appendix E Baseline Implementations

E.1 DreamBooth Training Settings

Here, we discuss the DreamBooth (Ruiz etÂ al., 2023) experiment design.

Input Images. Following the original DreamBooth paper that uses 3 to 5 input images, we ask human evaluators to select the top 4 best images among the initial batch of images generated for each task and use these selected images as training inputs.

Hyperparameters. We follow the common practice of training DreamBooth with LoRA (Hu etÂ al., 2022). Training hyperparameters are listed inÂ TableÂ 8.

Prior Preservation Loss (PPL). This function is enabled and uses the default setting where 100 class data images are generated from the class prompts.

Prompts. We experiment with various combinations of training prompt, PPL class prompt, and evaluation prompt, then choose the combinations shown inÂ TableÂ 9. SeeÂ SectionÂ B.3 for details on prompting experiments.

The outcome of DB training is influenced by multiple factors, including the number and selection of input images, training hyperparameters, use of PPL, and combination of prompts. While we optimized these elements for our tasks to the best of our ability, it is possible that further tuning can yield better results, as the large number of tunable variables makes DB challenging to optimize.

E.2 Prompt Enhancement with a Large VLM

In the SD-enhanced baselines, we prompt the Stable Diffusion v1.5 model with a prompt enhanced by GPT-4 (Brown, 2020; Achiam etÂ al., 2023). To generate the enhanced prompts, we input â€œEnhance the following text prompt for Stable Diffusion image generation: [prompt]â€ to GPT-4 ([prompt] is the original task prompt labeled â€Promptâ€ inÂ TableÂ 1 and â€Generation Promptâ€ inÂ TableÂ 10). Output-enhanced prompts used for the SD-enhanced baseline are shown inÂ TableÂ 10. Although our prompt enhancement is not an exhaustive method to show the full capabilities of prompt engineering, we include SD-enhanced as a baseline to demonstrate that many of our tasks are challenging to solve, given a simple prompt enhancement method.
